description: From Middle English four, from Old English fƒìower, from Proto-West Germanic *feuwar, from Proto-Germanic *fedw≈çr, from previous pre-Grimm *petw·πìr, from Proto-Indo-European *k ∑etw·πìr, the neuter form of *k ∑etw√≥res. Doublet of cuatro and quatre.

Cognates include West Frisian fjouwer, Dutch and German vier, Norwegian Bokm√•l and Danish fire, Swedish fyra, Gothic êçÜêåπêå≥êçÖêçâêçÇ (fidw≈çr) and, more distantly, Latin quattuor (whence Spanish cuatro, French quatre), Ancient Greek œÑŒ≠œÉœÉŒ±œÅŒµœÇ (t√©ssares), Irish ceathair, Armenian ’π’∏÷Ä’Ω (ƒç øors), Lithuanian keturi, Albanian kat√´r, Sanskrit ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç (catur).

entries.meaning: (countable) The digit or figure 4; an occurrence thereof.
(countable) Anything measuring four units, as length.
examples: Do you have any more fours? I want to make this a little taller.

entries.meaning: A person who is four years old.
examples: I'll take the threes, fours and fives and go to the playground.

entries.meaning: (cricket, countable) An event in which the batsmen run four times between the wickets or, more often, a batsman hits a ball which bounces on the ground before passing over a boundary, resulting in an award of 4 runs for the batting team. If the ball does not bounce before passing over the boundary, a six is awarded instead.

definitionGroups.group: (rowing) Four-man sweep racing shell, with or without a coxswain.

examples: The team bought a new four last season.

entries.meaning: The crew rowing in a four boat.
(colloquial) A regatta event for four boats.
examples: We got third place in the varsity four.
I was a-strollin' down, thinkin' between ourselves how uncommon handy a four of gin hot would be, when suddenly the glint of a light caught my eye in the window of that same house.
